info.game_comments:
1998 College Championship quarterfinal game 3.
From Zellerbach Auditorium at the University of California-Berkeley.

(1, 1).clue: This country's post-apartheid national anthem is "Nkosi Sikelel' Iafrka"

(2, 1).clue: Much of Pete's time is spent delivering copies of these proposed laws

(3, 1).clue: In "Contact", this actress doesn't go to Vegas but does try to reach the area of the star Vega

(4, 1).clue: If you try pouring the blackstrap type of this syrup in January, you may have to wait until February to eat it

(5, 1).clue: To counteract terrorism, President Clinton proposed increased FBI power to use this recording method

(6, 1).clue: It means not electric, when talking of guitar or piano

(1, 2).clue: For centuries before 1939, this country was known as Siam

(2, 2).clue: Pete thinks it's fitting that Republican senators sit to this side of the Democrats

(3, 2).clue: Yoda rode again in 1997 as this first "Star Wars" sequel was successfully re-released

(4, 2).clue: Cinematic effect achieved by filming at faster than projection speed

(5, 2).clue: DAT, which stands for this, uses the same coding system as CDs & allows for home recording

(1, 3).clue: This country was once part of the Roman Empire & its name means "Land of the Romans"

(2, 3).clue: Pete admires John Dingell, a former page who now represents this Wolverine State in the House

(3, 3).clue: Sigourney Weaver has played the intrepid Ripley in a series of films starting with this one in 1979

(4, 3).clue: As its name indicates, it's a slow pitch thrown after a fastball to upset the batter's timing

(5, 3).clue: Recording system that's the office counterpart of the home answering machine

(6, 3).clue: Never do this, as it "makes an ass out of U & me"

(1, 4).clue: Of Malta, Mauritius or Mauritania, the one that isn't an island

(2, 4).clue: This impressive area under the Capitol's dome made Pete dizzy the first time he saw it

(3, 4).clue: 5 years before "E.T.", little Cary Guffey tried to befriend extraterrestrials in this Spielberg film
(3, 4).correct response: Close Encounters of the Third Kind

(4, 4).clue: If you had only 1 foot & moved by contracting it, you'd also go at this gastropod's pace

(5, 4).clue: It's the most common term for inserting live sounds or bits of other albums into rap songs

(6, 4).clue: Appropriate Latin phrase to use when the commercial's been on for so long it's "making you sick"

(1, 5).clue: Burgenland, Vorarlberg & Salzburg are 3 of this German-speaking country's 9 provinces

(2, 5).clue: Pete's duties include preparing this room before the senators arrive for session in it

(3, 5).clue: The boundary of a black hole, this "horizon" was the title of a 1997 Laurence Fishburne flick

(4, 5).clue: A plant like ivy, that spreads across a surface, or a person who crawls slowly & stealthily

(5, 5).clue: A master mixing board, covered with cool levers & knobs; said another way, it means "to comfort"

(6, 5).clue: It's what Borgs do; it makes you one of them

(1, 1).correct response: Jose Carreras, Placido Domingo, Luciano Pavarotti

(2, 1).clue: In July 1877 the first tennis championships were played on a croquet lawn in this London suburb

(3, 1).clue: Click on this channel & you might find yourself in the middle of "Shark Week"

(4, 1).clue: This American botanist developed over 400 products from the sweet potato, the pecan & the peanut

(5, 1).clue: If you wear braces, these devices are attached to your teeth, & rubber ones may help move them

(6, 1).clue: Of his $20 million fee for "Air Force One", this actor said that it "shocks me, but that's the market"

(1, 2).clue: The first jazz artist to win a Music Pulitzer, this brother of Branford won for the opera "Blood on the Fields"

(2, 2).clue: This "affectionate" term refers to a score of zero

(3, 2).clue: If you like little bubbles of trivia with your videos, try "Pop-Up Video" on this channel

(4, 2).clue: In 1891 she moved from Poland to Paris, where she studied math & physics at the Sorbonne

(5, 2).clue: The panoramic type of this century-old diagnostic tool wiil show whether you have extra teeth

(6, 2).clue: On Sept. 6, 1997 her brother eulogized her by saying "She was the symbol of selfless humanity"

(1, 3).clue: Classic piece heard here with Melissa Joan Hart as Clarissa explaining it all

(2, 3).clue: This 17-year-old, then ranked No. 66, shook up women's tennis by reaching the 1997 U.S. Open final

(3, 3).clue: In early 1997, this show about robots who watch bad movies, moved from Comedy Central to Sci-Fi

(4, 3).clue: Italian whose legendary experiment is recreated in the exhibit (Leaning Tower of Pisa) seen here

(5, 3).clue: When Doc wants these, he's not asking you to imitate Elvis, he's going to get a model of your mouth

(6, 3).clue: On Feb. 9, 1941 Churchill told FDR, "Give us the tools and we will" do this

(1, 4).clue: Considered an heir to Beethoven, Gustav Mahler, like Ludwig, completed only this many symphonies

(2, 4).clue: At the center, a tennis net should be exactly this many feet high

(3, 4).clue: It's the obvious name for a cable network that runs "Johnny Bravo" & "Speed Racer"

(4, 4).clue: Last name of the husband, wife & son paleoanthropologists Louis, Mary & Richard

(5, 4).clue: Diastema is the technical name of this condition for which David Letterman is famous

(6, 4).clue: This poet wrote, "I celebrate myself and sing myself"; he was a one-man party

(1, 5).clue: Aaron Copland's "Fanfare for the Common Man", heard here, is commonly associated with this sports event

(2, 5).clue: She retired in 1994 with career earnings of over $20 million, a figure then exceeded by only Ivan Lendl

(3, 5).clue: Between shows on this new network, you may have seen the stars do the "Dubba" dance

(4, 5).clue: This English astronomer taught himself architecture & designed St. Paul's Cathedral

(5, 5).clue: 4-letter synonym for occlusion, the relationship between upper & lower teeth with your mouth shut

(6, 5).clue: This Prussian king's last words, spoken at Potsdam, were, "I am tired of ruling over slaves"

(0, 0).clue: Unopposed, he was elected to his 5th term as president in 1998; he's been in power since 1959
